questions.question: To verify the existence of investments in marketable securities held by a custodian, the auditor would most likely:

options.A: Review the client's investment policy
options.B: Confirm the securities held with the custodian
options.C: Vouch purchases to broker advices
options.D: Compare market values to original cost

questions.explanation: Confirmation with the independent custodian is the primary procedure for verifying the existence of securities held externally. The custodian can confirm the quantity, description, and ownership of securities in the client's name.
questions.tip: Securities held by custodian = confirm with custodian for existence.

questions.question: When securities are held by the client, the auditor should count them:

options.A: At any time during the year
options.B: Simultaneously with the cash count at year-end
options.C: Only if they represent more than 50% of total assets
options.D: At least one month before year-end

questions.explanation: When the client holds securities, they should be counted simultaneously with the cash count to prevent the client from substituting cash or securities to cover a shortage in one or the other. This simultaneous control prevents manipulation.
questions.tip: Count securities and cash at same time—prevents moving money to cover shortages.

questions.question: Under ASC 320, debt securities that management has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are classified as:

options.A: Trading securities
options.B: Available-for-sale securities
options.C: Held-to-maturity securities
options.D: Equity method investments

questions.explanation: Held-to-maturity securities are debt securities that management has both the positive intent and ability to hold until maturity. They are reported at amortized cost rather than fair value. Any sale of HTM securities (except in limited circumstances) taints the entire HTM portfolio.
questions.tip: HTM = debt only + intent and ability to hold = amortized cost.

questions.question: Trading securities are reported on the balance sheet at:

options.A: Original cost
options.B: Lower of cost or market
options.C: Fair value with unrealized gains and losses in net income
options.D: Fair value with unrealized gains and losses in OCI

questions.explanation: Trading securities are reported at fair value with all unrealized gains and losses recognized in net income. This differs from available-for-sale securities, where unrealized gains and losses are reported in OCI.
questions.tip: Trading = fair value, gains/losses in income. AFS = fair value, gains/losses in OCI.

questions.question: The equity method of accounting is generally required when an investor has:

options.A: Any investment in common stock
options.B: Ownership of 20% to 50% of voting stock with significant influence
options.C: Ownership of more than 50% of voting stock
options.D: Any investment in debt securities

questions.explanation: The equity method is used when the investor has significant influence over the investee, typically presumed with 20% to 50% ownership of voting stock. The investor records its share of investee earnings/losses and adjusts the investment accordingly.
questions.tip: 20-50% ownership with influence = equity method. Over 50% = consolidation.

questions.question: When auditing investments, examining broker advices and statements provides evidence primarily about:

options.A: Future market trends
options.B: Purchase and sale transactions and holdings
options.C: Management's investment strategy
options.D: Adequacy of internal controls

questions.explanation: Broker advices and statements provide evidence of investment transactions (purchases and sales) and period-end holdings. These external documents support the existence, completeness, and valuation of investments.
questions.tip: Broker advices = evidence for transactions and period-end holdings.

questions.question: Level 1 inputs in the fair value hierarchy are:

options.A: Unobservable inputs based on the entity's own assumptions
options.B: Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities
options.C: Observable inputs other than quoted prices for identical items
options.D: Discounted cash flow models developed by management

questions.explanation: Level 1 inputs are quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities that the entity can access at the measurement date. These provide the most reliable evidence of fair value.
questions.tip: Level 1 = quoted prices for identical items in active markets (most reliable).

questions.question: When investments are valued using Level 3 inputs, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept management's valuation without further testing
options.B: Perform more extensive procedures to evaluate the inputs and methodology
options.C: Issue a qualified opinion due to uncertainty
options.D: Require the client to use Level 1 inputs instead

questions.explanation: Level 3 inputs are unobservable and require significant judgment. The auditor should perform more extensive procedures including evaluating the valuation methodology, testing significant assumptions, and considering the need for a valuation specialist.
questions.tip: Level 3 = unobservable inputs = requires more audit scrutiny.

questions.conceptTested: Credit loss model for debt securities
questions.question: Under ASU 2016-13 (CECL model), available-for-sale debt securities with declines in fair value below amortized cost:

options.A: Always require immediate impairment recognition
options.B: Require evaluation of credit losses versus non-credit losses
options.C: Are never impaired
options.D: Are written down to fair value through retained earnings

questions.explanation: For AFS debt securities, declines below amortized cost must be evaluated to determine the portion attributable to credit losses (recorded through allowance account affecting earnings) versus non-credit factors (recorded in OCI). Intent and ability to hold affects the analysis.
questions.tip: AFS decline = split between credit loss (income) and non-credit loss (OCI).

questions.question: When auditing equity method investments, the auditor should:

options.A: Confirm the investment balance with the investee
options.B: Obtain and evaluate the investee's financial statements and verify the investor's share of earnings
options.C: Only test if the investment is material to the financial statements
options.D: Accept management's calculation without independent verification

questions.explanation: The auditor should obtain the investee's financial statements (audited if material), verify the percentage ownership, recalculate the investor's share of investee earnings/losses, and evaluate any basis differences from the acquisition.
questions.tip: Equity method = get investee F/S + verify ownership % + recalculate income pickup.

questions.question: When an investor owns more than 50% of the voting stock of an investee, the appropriate accounting treatment is generally:

options.A: Cost method
options.B: Equity method
options.C: Consolidation of financial statements
options.D: Fair value through net income

questions.explanation: Majority ownership (over 50% of voting stock) typically results in control, requiring consolidation of the subsidiary's financial statements with the parent. The investment account is eliminated in consolidation and replaced with the subsidiary's assets and liabilities.
questions.tip: Over 50% ownership = control = consolidation required.

questions.question: When auditing dividend income, the auditor should:

options.A: Confirm dividends received with the investee company
options.B: Verify dividend income by reference to published dividend records
options.C: Accept management's records without independent verification
options.D: Only test dividends from related parties

questions.explanation: Dividend income can be independently verified using published dividend information (dividend services, financial publications, or investee's investor relations). The auditor can compare recorded dividends to published records based on shares held and ex-dividend dates.
questions.tip: Verify dividends using published dividend records—independent and reliable.

questions.question: A substantive test of interest income from debt securities would include:

options.A: Confirming interest income with the SEC
options.B: Recalculating expected interest income based on holdings and stated rates
options.C: Accepting broker statements as sole evidence
options.D: Testing only if interest income exceeds prior year

questions.explanation: Interest income can be tested by recalculating expected amounts based on the face value of securities held, stated interest rates, and the holding period. This analytical procedure provides strong evidence for interest income reasonableness.
questions.tip: Recalculate interest: face value × rate × time held = expected income.

questions.question: When auditing realized gains and losses on investment sales, the auditor should:

options.A: Only review gains since losses may indicate impairment
options.B: Verify the proceeds and original cost basis, and recalculate the gain or loss
options.C: Accept the broker's calculation as sufficient evidence
options.D: Test only transactions over a dollar threshold

questions.explanation: The auditor should verify sales proceeds (from broker advices or confirmations), verify the original cost basis (from purchase records), and recalculate the gain or loss. For AFS securities, any amounts in AOCI must also be reclassified.
questions.tip: Realized gain/loss = verify proceeds - verify cost = recalculate.

questions.question: When auditing investments in related parties, the auditor should:

options.A: Apply the same procedures as for unrelated investments
options.B: Pay particular attention to valuation, arm's-length terms, and proper disclosure
options.C: Rely on management's representations about the relationship
options.D: Only disclose the relationship if asked by regulators

questions.explanation: Related party investments require heightened scrutiny regarding valuation (which may not be at arm's length), the economic substance of the transaction, and proper disclosure of the relationship and terms. These investments may not reflect market conditions.
questions.tip: Related party investments = increased scrutiny on valuation and disclosure.

questions.question: If a client sells held-to-maturity securities before maturity for reasons other than those specified in the standards:

options.A: The transaction is reversed
options.B: The remaining HTM portfolio may be tainted, requiring reclassification
options.C: Only that specific security is affected
options.D: The auditor must disclaim an opinion

questions.explanation: Selling HTM securities before maturity (except for specified circumstances like credit deterioration or changes in tax law) calls into question management's intent to hold other HTM securities. This may 'taint' the portfolio, requiring reclassification to AFS.
questions.tip: Selling HTM early can taint the whole portfolio—questions intent to hold.

questions.question: Reviewing the client's investment policy helps the auditor:

options.A: Determine the risk of material misstatement by understanding authorized investments and limits
options.B: Predict future investment returns
options.C: Confirm all investments are profitable
options.D: Assess management's personal investment acumen

questions.explanation: The investment policy establishes authorized investments, concentration limits, and risk parameters. Understanding the policy helps the auditor assess whether investments are authorized, identify potential policy violations, and evaluate related controls.
questions.tip: Investment policy review = understand what's authorized + identify violations.

questions.question: When auditing investments in hedge funds or private equity funds, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the fund manager's NAV statement as sufficient evidence
options.B: Evaluate the investee fund's financial statements and consider the qualifications of the fund auditor
options.C: Require the client to divest of such investments
options.D: Only confirm that the investment exists

questions.explanation: For alternative investments, the auditor should evaluate the investee fund's audited financial statements (if available), consider the fund auditor's qualifications, assess the appropriateness of using NAV as fair value, and evaluate any redemption restrictions affecting valuation.
questions.tip: Hedge fund investments = get fund F/S + evaluate fund auditor + assess NAV appropriateness.

questions.question: Non-marketable equity securities without a readily determinable fair value are measured under ASC 321 at:

options.A: Cost with impairment testing only
options.B: Fair value with changes in OCI
options.C: Cost minus impairment plus or minus observable price changes
options.D: Lower of cost or market

questions.explanation: Under ASC 321, equity securities without readily determinable fair values are measured at cost minus impairment, plus or minus changes resulting from observable price changes in orderly transactions for identical or similar investments of the same issuer.
questions.tip: Non-marketable equity = cost ± observable price changes - impairment.

questions.question: Proper segregation of duties over investments requires that:

options.A: The same person can authorize, execute, and record transactions if supervised
options.B: Authorization, custody, and record-keeping functions are performed by different individuals
options.C: Only the CFO handles all investment functions
options.D: External custodians are never used

questions.explanation: Proper segregation of duties requires separating the functions of authorizing transactions, maintaining custody of securities, and recording transactions. This prevents any single individual from both perpetrating and concealing irregularities.
questions.tip: Investment controls = separate authorization, custody, and record-keeping.

questions.question: When investments are transferred between categories (e.g., from AFS to trading), the auditor should:

options.A: Ignore the transfer since the investment still exists
options.B: Evaluate the appropriateness and accounting for the transfer at fair value
options.C: Require reversal of the transfer
options.D: Accept management's justification without testing

questions.explanation: Transfers between categories must be evaluated for appropriateness and proper accounting. Transfers are made at fair value, and any unrealized gain or loss handling depends on the direction of transfer. Frequent transfers may indicate management attempting to manage earnings.
questions.tip: Test transfers for appropriateness—frequent transfers may signal earnings management.

questions.question: When a client elects the fair value option for an investment under ASC 825, the auditor should verify:

options.A: The election was properly made at inception and fair value is reliably measurable
options.B: The election can be changed at any time
options.C: Only equity investments qualify for the fair value option
options.D: The fair value option reduces audit procedures

questions.explanation: The fair value option under ASC 825 is an irrevocable election made at inception of the instrument. The auditor should verify proper election timing, ensure fair value is reliably determinable, and test the fair value measurement including inputs and methodology.
questions.tip: Fair value option = irrevocable election at inception + must test fair value measurement.

questions.question: When evaluating whether an investment in a variable interest entity (VIE) requires consolidation, the auditor should determine if the client is:

options.A: A 50% or more owner
options.B: The primary beneficiary with power to direct activities and obligation to absorb losses or receive benefits
options.C: An investor in any structured entity
options.D: Related to the VIE through common management

questions.explanation: Under the VIE model, consolidation is based on the primary beneficiary concept rather than voting control. The primary beneficiary has both the power to direct activities that most significantly impact the VIE's economic performance AND the obligation to absorb losses or receive benefits.
questions.tip: VIE consolidation = power over significant activities + absorb losses/receive benefits.

questions.question: When the cost of an equity method investment exceeds the investor's share of underlying book value, the auditor should verify that:

options.A: The excess is immediately expensed
options.B: The basis difference is allocated to identifiable assets/liabilities and any remainder treated as goodwill
options.C: The investment is written down to book value
options.D: The excess is reported in OCI

questions.explanation: When acquisition cost exceeds book value, the difference must be allocated to identifiable assets (depreciated/amortized) and liabilities of the investee with any residual treated as equity method goodwill. The auditor should verify proper allocation and amortization.
questions.tip: Equity method premium = allocate to assets/liabilities + remainder is goodwill.

questions.question: When auditing derivative investments, the auditor should:

options.A: Only confirm existence with the counterparty
options.B: Understand the instrument's terms, verify fair value, and evaluate hedge accounting if applicable
options.C: Accept management's valuation since derivatives are complex
options.D: Require the client to engage a specialist

questions.explanation: Derivative auditing requires understanding the contractual terms, evaluating fair value measurement (including Level 2/3 inputs), testing hedge effectiveness if hedge accounting is applied, and verifying proper classification and disclosure.
questions.tip: Derivatives = understand terms + verify fair value + test hedge accounting if used.

questions.question: For investments designated as hedging instruments, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the hedge designation without testing
options.B: Evaluate whether hedge documentation exists and test hedge effectiveness
options.C: Only test if the hedge is ineffective
options.D: Require the client to discontinue hedge accounting

questions.explanation: Hedge accounting requires formal documentation at inception designating the hedging relationship. The auditor should verify documentation exists, evaluate whether the hedge is expected to be and actually is highly effective, and verify proper accounting for effective and ineffective portions.
questions.tip: Hedge accounting = verify documentation + test prospective and retrospective effectiveness.

questions.question: When auditing investment real estate held for income or appreciation, the auditor should:

options.A: Only confirm ownership through title searches
options.B: Evaluate carrying value, assess for impairment, and consider fair value disclosures
options.C: Accept the tax assessed value as fair value
options.D: Require annual appraisals regardless of impairment indicators

questions.explanation: Investment real estate requires evaluation of carrying value (cost or fair value depending on entity type), impairment assessment based on recoverability tests, and fair value disclosures. The auditor may need to evaluate appraisals and significant valuation assumptions.
questions.tip: Investment property = verify carrying value + test impairment + evaluate fair value disclosures.

questions.question: When auditing a significant investment in a joint venture, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the JV financial statements without further procedures
options.B: Perform procedures on the JV financial information or obtain and evaluate the JV auditor's work
options.C: Only confirm the investment percentage
options.D: Require the client to consolidate the joint venture

questions.explanation: For significant joint venture investments, the auditor should obtain the JV's financial information, evaluate its adequacy for the investor's reporting, and either perform procedures directly or evaluate the JV auditor's work. The equity method pickup must be verified.
questions.tip: Significant JV = get financial info + either audit directly or evaluate JV auditor's work.

questions.question: When auditing cryptocurrency investments, the auditor should consider:

options.A: Only the blockchain confirmation of ownership
options.B: Existence verification (wallet access/blockchain), valuation challenges, and proper accounting treatment
options.C: That crypto assets always qualify as cash equivalents
options.D: That no audit procedures are possible for crypto

questions.explanation: Crypto audit considerations include: verifying existence through wallet access or blockchain analysis, addressing valuation challenges (multiple exchanges, thin markets, 24/7 trading), and determining proper accounting (generally as indefinite-lived intangibles under current GAAP).
questions.tip: Crypto = verify via blockchain/wallet + address valuation challenges + classify properly.

questions.question: Under the current expected credit loss (CECL) model for held-to-maturity debt securities:

options.A: Impairment is only recognized when it is probable
options.B: An allowance for expected credit losses is recognized at inception based on lifetime expected losses
options.C: Fair value changes affect net income immediately
options.D: No impairment testing is required

questions.explanation: Under CECL, entities must recognize an allowance for expected credit losses on HTM securities at inception, based on lifetime expected losses rather than waiting for a triggering event. This differs from the old OTTI model that required probable loss recognition.
questions.tip: CECL for HTM = recognize expected losses at inception (lifetime loss estimate).

questions.question: When using net asset value (NAV) as a practical expedient for fair value measurement, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept NAV without additional procedures
options.B: Evaluate whether NAV is an appropriate measure and assess any restrictions or other factors affecting value
options.C: Always require a third-party valuation
options.D: Classify the investment as Level 1

questions.explanation: When using NAV as a practical expedient, the auditor should evaluate whether NAV is calculated consistently with ASC 820, assess redemption restrictions that might affect realizable value, consider timing differences between NAV date and balance sheet date, and review the fund's audited financials.
questions.tip: NAV expedient = evaluate appropriateness + consider restrictions + timing issues.

questions.question: When evaluating whether an investment requires consolidation under the voting interest model, the auditor should consider:

options.A: Only the percentage of shares owned
options.B: Voting rights, potential voting rights, contractual arrangements, and ability to direct activities
options.C: Whether the investee is profitable
options.D: Management's preference for consolidation

questions.explanation: Control assessment requires evaluating current voting rights, potential voting rights from convertible instruments or options, contractual arrangements that may convey control, kick-out rights, and participating rights that could overcome the presumption of control.
questions.tip: Consolidation = evaluate all factors affecting control, not just ownership percentage.

questions.question: When auditing hybrid instruments (debt with embedded derivatives), the auditor should:

options.A: Account for the instrument as a single unit in all cases
options.B: Evaluate whether the embedded derivative requires bifurcation and separate accounting
options.C: Ignore the embedded feature if it is out-of-the-money
options.D: Always bifurcate the derivative component

questions.explanation: The auditor should evaluate whether an embedded derivative meets the criteria for bifurcation: (1) the economic characteristics are not clearly and closely related to the host, (2) a separate instrument with same terms would be a derivative, and (3) the hybrid is not measured at fair value with changes in earnings.
questions.tip: Embedded derivatives = evaluate bifurcation criteria (not clearly related + would be derivative).

questions.question: When auditing restricted securities (e.g., Rule 144 stock), the auditor should:

options.A: Use the publicly traded price without adjustment
options.B: Evaluate whether a discount for lack of marketability is appropriate and reasonably determined
options.C: Value at zero until restrictions lapse
options.D: Require immediate sale upon restriction lapse

questions.explanation: Restricted securities may require a discount from the publicly traded price to reflect the restriction on marketability. The auditor should evaluate whether a discount is appropriate, assess the reasonableness of the discount rate, and consider factors like restriction period and trading volume.
questions.tip: Restricted stock = evaluate marketability discount for lack of liquidity.

questions.question: When auditing an investment company under ASC 946, the auditor should be aware that:

options.A: Investment companies follow the same GAAP as operating companies
options.B: All investments are measured at fair value, and specialized industry accounting applies
options.C: Investment companies are exempt from fair value disclosures
options.D: Only publicly traded investments are reported at fair value

questions.explanation: Investment companies under ASC 946 measure all investments at fair value with changes in earnings, do not consolidate majority-owned investees, and follow specialized industry accounting. The auditor must understand these differences and apply appropriate procedures to fair value measurements.
questions.tip: Investment companies = all investments at fair value + no consolidation + specialized GAAP.
